column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=webanno.custom.NamedEntityexactmatch|value
#Text=Mechanical biliary obstruction results in raised levels of ALP, GGT and often bilirubin.
#Text=ALP will usually be markedly raised in comparison with ALT.
#Text=Levels of ALP and GGT elevated in similar proportions signify a hepatobiliary source.
#Text=Otherwise alternative causes of single enzyme elevation should be considered.
#Text=When due to choledocholithiasis, the levels of ALP and GGT tend to fluctuate (in comparison to stricture forming disease) and may be associated with a normal bilirubin.
#Text=Enzyme titres tend to rise and fall gradually and may be preceded by a peaked rise in liver transaminases which can reach > 1000I/U.
#Text=The AST:ALT ratio (De Ritis ratio) may assist in differentiating the site of biliary obstruction.
#Text=When associated with a cholestatic picture, an AST:ALT ratio of <1.5 suggests an extrahepatic obstruction.
#Text=In such circumstances the ALT titre is frequently considerably higher than AST.
#Text=An AST:ALT ratio of > 1.5 indicates intrahepatic (mechanical or medical) cholestasis is more likely.
#Text=Drug-induced cholestasis usually presents with a preferential rise in ALP, rather than GGT, or with an ALT:ALP ratio of<2.
#Text=Causative drugs would include: antibiotics, immunosuppressants, tricyclic antidepressants and angiotensin converting enzyme inhibitors.
#Text=In Primary Biliary Cirrhosis, an autoimmune condition of the intrahepatic biliary ducts, the level of ALP is generally greater than that of GGT.
#Text=In this case, transaminases are invariably normal or only minimally elevated.
#Text=If either of these two criteria is absent, imaging and liver biopsy become necessary.
#Text=AST and ALP are used within some scoring criteria to monitor the effects of ursodeoxycholic acid in the management of PBC.
#Text=A recent study has shown that a raised AST:ALT ratio outperforms other non-histological indicators of cirrhosis in PBC, but still only achieves a low sensitivity and a specificity of 65-79%.
#Text=As with PBC, liver enzymes play a key role in the diagnosis of Primary Sclerosing Cholangitis (PSC).
#Text=Alcohol induces hepatic enzymes leading to a raised GGT with an ALP which may be normal, or disproportionately lower than the GGT.
#Text=A GGT: ALP ratio > 2.5 in association with jaundice suggests alcohol as a cause of liver disease.

#Text=The presence of a macrocytosis, due to either an associated dietary deficiency of folate or B12, or due to a direct suppression of bone marrow by alcohol is supportive of the diagnosis of alcoholic liver disease.
#Text=A raised GGT is not diagnostic of alcohol abuse, with research showing it remains high in former drinkers as well as current drinkers.
